title: Back‐to‐Land Movement Seeks Self‐Sufficiency
description: NY Times survey finds self-sufficiency has become battle-cry of full-scale back-to-the-land movement that has attracted thousands of Amers since antiwar movement of '60s; finds established politics and economics are beginning to feel impact of movement, especially in New England, and that scattering of extension service agents and other Govt agr officers have begun to take it seriously in several states; cites broad aim of movement as seeking ways to live simply but well on the land outside econ insts that dominate US; finds movement is deeply antagonistic to Amer econ system, whose adherents it sees as controlled by unbridled corp power, corrupted with surfeit and crazed by impulse to consume and waste; finds most back-to-the-land advocates are young and believe movement will have impact on Amer system comparable to Civil Rights movement; notes recent Census Bur svy which shows rural areas have been gaining population faster than urban areas since '70; migration to New England, W Coast, Vt, Rocky Mts, Southern highlands, Upper Middle West, Pa, NY, Ore and Ozarks noted; illus (L)
dc:creator: Roy Reed Special to The New York Times
